common_mistakes.correction: If you just need the same image in different sizes/resolutions, use with `srcset`. Use only when changing the art/crop.
The element itself displays nothing. You MUST include an tag inside it.

interview_questions.question: Difference between srcset and picture?
interview_questions.answer: Use `srcset` when you want to serve the SAME image in different resolutions (performance). Use `<picture>` when you want to serve a DIFFERENT image (cropping, aspect ratio) based on device (art direction) or different formats (WebP vs JPG).

interview_questions.question: What is the 'w' descriptor in srcset?
interview_questions.answer: It tells the browser the real width of the image file (e.g., 500w means 500px wide), allowing the browser to calculate which image to fetch based on screen density (DPR) and layout size.

practice_problems.problem: Create a responsive image setup that serves 'logo-large.png' for screens wider than 1000px and 'logo-small.png' otherwise.

real_world_use_cases.description: Blogs serve WebP images to Chrome/Edge users and JPG to old Safari users using <picture> for better performance.

summary: Responsive images ensure your website looks great and loads fast on any device. By using `srcset` for resolution switching or `<picture>` for explicit control, you avoid sending large desktop files to mobile users.
